facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 295-297 of 1974 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 295-297 of 1974. Under article 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Bhuvan Mohan Patnaik is petitioner in Writ Petition No. 295 of 1974 and is undergoing sentences of 4 1/2 years and 5 1/2 years awarded in two sessions cases.

anchor.surface_text: Bhuvan Mohan Patnaik, the petitioner in Writ Petition No. 295 of 1974 is undergoing the sentences of 4 1/2 years and 5 1/2 year awarded to him in two sessions cases.

facts.text: Bhuvan Mohan Patnaik is an under-trial prisoner in the Parvatipuram Naxalite Conspiracy case.

anchor.surface_text: He is also an under trial prisoner in what is known as the Parvatipuram Naxalite Conspiracy case.

facts.text: Nagabhushan Patnaik is petitioner in Writ Petition No. 296 of 1974.

anchor.surface_text: Nagabhushan Patnaik, who is the petitioner in Writ Petition No. 296 of 1974 was sentenced to death by the learned 11 Additional Sessions Judge, Visakhapatnam,

facts.text: Nagabhushan Patnaik was sentenced to death by the 11 Additional Sessions Judge, Visakhapatnam, commuted to life imprisonment by the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: but that sentence was companymuted by the State Government to life imprisonment.

facts.text: P. Hussainar is petitioner in Writ Petition No. 297 of 1974.

anchor.surface_text: P. Hussainar, the petitioner in Writ Petition No. 297 of 1974, is undergoing the sentence of imprisonment for life imposed by the same learned Judge.

facts.text: P. Hussainar is undergoing life imprisonment imposed by the 11 Additional Sessions Judge, Visakhapatnam.

anchor.surface_text: He is also an under-trial prisoner in the Parvatipuram Case.

facts.text: P. Hussainar is an under-trial prisoner in the Parvatipuram Case.

anchor.surface_text: The three petitioners are undergoing the sentences in the Central Jail at Visakhapatnam.

facts.text: The three petitioners are undergoing sentences in the Central Jail at Visakhapatnam.

anchor.surface_text: The three petitioners are undergoing the sentences in the Central Jail at Visakhapatnam.

facts.text: Petitioners seek removal of armed police guards posted around the jail.

anchor.surface_text: The only reliefs which they ask for are  1 that the armed police guards posted around the jail should be removed

facts.text: Petitioners seek dismantling of the livewire electrical mechanism fixed on top of the jail wall.

anchor.surface_text: and  2  that the livewire electrical mechanism fixed on top of the jail wall should be dismantled.

facts.text: Superintendent of Central Jail, Visakhapatnam (3rd respondent) filed an affidavit stating usual watch and ward staff inadequate, requisitioned Andhra Pradesh Special Police Force to guard jail from outside.

anchor.surface_text: The Superintendent of the Central Jail, Visakhapatnam, who is the 3rd respondent to the petitions, has filed an affidavit stating that the usual watch and ward staff of the jail having been found to be inadequate, the services of the Andhra Pradesh Special Police Force had to be requisitioned to guard the, jail from outside.

facts.text: Policemen of AP Special Police Force live in huts built on vacant jail land.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit shows that these policemen live in huts built on a part of the vacant jail land

facts.text: Officers of AP Special Police Force accommodated in jail Club outside the jail.

anchor.surface_text: and that the officers of the Force are, accommodated in the. jail Club immediately outside the jail.

facts.text: Office of AP Special Police Force in block outside jail meant for visitors' waiting room.

anchor.surface_text: Their office is situated in a block outside the jail, which was meant to be used as a waiting room for visitors wishing to meet the prisoners.

facts.text: 146 Naxalite prisoners lodged in Visakhapatnam jail, making usual watch inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit of the third respondent shows that as many as 146 Naxalite prisoners were lodged in the Visakhapatnam jail as a result of which the usual watch and ward arrangement proved inadequate.

facts.text: 11 Naxalite prisoners including Nagabhushan Patnaik and P. Hussainar escaped from Visakhapatnam prison on the night of October 8, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Eleven Naxalite prisoners including two out of the three petitioners before us, namely, Nagabhushan Patnaik and P. Hussainar, escaped from the prison on the night of October 8, 1969.

facts.text: Live-wire installed on top of wall 14 feet from ground level, wall height 13 feet.

anchor.surface_text: The live-wire is installed on the top of a wall, 14 feet from the ground level, the height of the wall itself being 13 feet.

facts.text: Live-wire rests on enamel non-conductors fixed to angle irons embedded in wall, no direct contact with wall.

anchor.surface_text: It rests on enamel number-conductors fixed to angle irons which are embedded in the wall. The wire has numberdirect companytact with the wall

facts.text: Prison walls situated 20 feet from cells where petitioners lodged.

anchor.surface_text: The prison-walls are themselves situated at a distance of about 20 feet from the cells where the petitioners are lodged.

facts.text: Electrician inspects live-wire system regularly.

anchor.surface_text: An electrician inspects the system regularly.

facts.text: Prisoners warned of live-wire existence, non-electrical barbed-wire fences jail walls.

anchor.surface_text: Family, the mechanism is number a secret trap as all prisoners are warned of its existence and a number-electrical barbed-wire fences the jail walls.

facts.text: Petitioners allege segregation of Naxalite prisoners in quarantine and inhuman treatment.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioners companyplained bitterly against the segregation of Naxalite prisoners in a quarantine and the inhuman treatment meted out to them

facts.text: Large number of Naxalite prisoners on marathon hunger-strike for improvement in conditions.

anchor.surface_text: But attention of the jail authorities needs to be drawn to what the petitioners have described as the marathon hunger- strike by a large number of Naxalite prisoners

facts.text: Court holds no deprivation of fundamental rights by posting of police guards outside jail.

anchor.surface_text: we are unable to appreciate that the petitioners have been deprived of any of their fundamental rights by the posting of police guards immediately outside the jail.

issues.text: Whether the posting of armed police guards around the jail on appurtenant land constitutes occupation of part of the prison and causes substantial interference with the fundamental rights of prisoners

anchor.surface_text: The only reliefs which they ask for are  1 that the armed police guards posted around the jail should be removed and  2  that the livewire electrical mechanism fixed on top of the jail wall should be dismantled. Mr. Garg who appears on behalf of the petitioners companytends that even the discipline of the prison must have the authority of law and that there should be a sort of Iron curtain between the prisoners and the police so that companyvicts and under-trial prisoners may be truly free from the influence and tyranny of the police. Section 3 1  of the Prisons Act, 9 of 1894, defines prison to mean any jail or place used permanently or temporarily

issues.text: Whether the treatment and conditions meted out to Naxalite prisoners in the jail, including segregation and denial of amenities, violate Article 21 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioners companyplained bitterly against the segregation of Naxalite prisoners in a quarantine and the inhuman treatment meted out to them as if they were inmates of a fascist companycentration camp. We would like to emphasis once again, and numberemphasis in this companytext can be too great, that though the Government possesses the companystitutional right to initiate laws, it cannot, by taking law into its own hands, resort to oppressive measures to curb the political beliefs of its opponents. No person, number even a prisoner, can be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.

issues.text: Whether the live-wire electrical mechanism fixed atop the jail walls is unconstitutional as it lacks authority of law, subjects escaping prisoners to death penalty, and violates personal liberty under Article 21

anchor.surface_text: As regards the live-wire mechanism fixed atop the jail walls. Mr. Garg argues that the act is unconstitutional because a prisoner attempting to escape is, by the use of the device, virtually subjected to a death penalty. The policy of law as reflected in section 224 of the, Penal Code, says the companynsel, is to visit a prisoner attempting to escape, or successfully escaping, to a maximum sentence of two years and a fine. The live wire gadget lacks the authority of law and since it is a flagrant violation of the personal liberty guaranteed by Article 21 of the Constitution, it must be declared unconstitutional.

issues.text: Whether prison security measures like live-wire require a statutory basis or procedure established by law if they infringe fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: This, in our opinion, is a wrong approach to the issue under companysideration. If the petitioners succeed in establishing that the particular measure taken by the jail authorities violates any of the fundamental rights available to them under the Constitution, the justification of the measure must be sought in some law, within the meaning of Article 13 3   a  of the Constitution. The installation of the high voltage wires lacks a statutory basis and seems to have been devised on the strength of departmental instructions. Such instructions are neither law within the meaning of Article 13 3   a  number are they procedure established by law within the meaning of Article 21 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Armed police guards posted around the jail on appurtenant land occupy part of the prison and cause substantial interference with the fundamental rights of prisoners

anchor.surface_text: The only reliefs which they ask for are  1 that the armed police guards posted around the jail should be removed and  2  that the livewire electrical mechanism fixed on top of the jail wall should be dismantled. Mr. Garg who appears on behalf of the petitioners contends that even the discipline of the prison must have the authority of law and that there should be a sort of Iron curtain between the prisoners and the police so that convicts and under-trial prisoners may be truly free from the influence and tyranny of the police. Section 3 1  of the Prisons Act, 9 of 1894, defines prison to mean any jail or place used permanently or temporarily

arguments.claim: No convict has right to dictate security measures against escape

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that a convict has any right any more than anyone else has, to dictate whether guards ought to be posted to prevent the escape of prisoners.

arguments.claim: Infiltration of police into prisons deprecated but here no access, hypothetical

anchor.surface_text: The infiltration of policemen into prisons must generally be deprecated... But the argument of Mr. Garg proceeds from purely hypothetical considerations.

arguments.claim: Live-wire does not infringe fundamental rights as no right to escape; only contact if attempting escape

anchor.surface_text: Whatever be the nature and extent of the petitioners fundamental right to life and personal liberty, they have no fundamental freedom to escape from lawful custody. Therefore, they cannot complain of the installation of the live-wire mechanism with which they are likely to come into contact only if they attempt to escape from the, prison.

arguments.claim: If measure violates FR, must have basis in law per Art 13(3)(a) and procedure under Art 21; here departmental instructions insufficient but no violation anyway

holdings.text: The petitioners have not been deprived of any fundamental rights by the posting of police guards immediately outside the jail.

anchor.surface_text: we are unable to appreciate that the petitioners have been deprived of any of their fundamental rights by the posting of police guards immediately outside the jail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Police are outside high walls with no access to jail; necessary due to 146 Naxalite prisoners and prior escapes; no interference with personal liberty.

holdings.text: Even a convict is entitled to the right under Article 21 and shall not be deprived of life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.

anchor.surface_text: Article 21 of the Constitution that he shall not be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirms existing law; incarceration deprives some freedoms inherently but not Art 21 protections; cites precedent like State of Maharashtra v. Prabhakar.

holdings.text: Vacant land appurtenant to the jail is part of the prison itself under section 3(1) of the Prisons Act.

anchor.surface_text: The vacant land appurtenant to the jail is by the definition of prison in section 3 (1) of the Prisons Act a part of the prison itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory definition; police occupation on such land does not interfere with prisoners' rights.

holdings.text: A convict has no right to dictate whether guards ought to be posted to prevent the escape of prisoners.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that a convict has any right any more than anyone else has, to dictate whether guards ought to be posted to prevent the escape of prisoners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prisoners cannot demand removal of security measures designed to prevent escapes; public interest in security.

holdings.text: The segregation of Naxalite prisoners and alleged inhuman treatment do not violate Article 21 for want of satisfactory proof.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioners complained bitterly against the segregation of Naxalite prisoners in a quarantine and the inhuman treatment meted out to them

holdings.reasoning_summary: No satisfactory evidence of violations; allegations not proven despite affidavits.

holdings.text: Denial of certain jail amenities does not necessarily constitute an encroachment on the right guaranteed by Article 21.

anchor.surface_text: there denial may not necessarily constitute an encroachment on the right guaranteed by Article 21 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 21 protects life and liberty, not all amenities; matters of reform but not constitutional violations without proof.

holdings.text: The live-wire mechanism does not interfere with any fundamental rights as prisoners have no fundamental freedom to escape from lawful custody.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever be the nature and extent of the petitioners fundamental right to life and personal liberty, they have no fundamental freedom to escape from lawful custody.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contact only if attempting illegal escape; preventive and deterrent, not causing death per se; analogous to high walls.

holdings.text: If a prison security measure violates fundamental rights, its justification must be in some law within Article 13(3)(a) or procedure under Article 21; departmental instructions insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: If the petitioners succeed in establishing that the particular measure taken by the jail authorities violates any of the fundamental rights... within the meaning of Article 13 (3) (a)

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects reasonableness test alone; requires statutory basis for FR infringements; but no violation here so moot.

holdings.text: Section 46 CrPC does not apply to the live-wire as it is preventive, not causing death by itself, unlike force in arrest or retaking.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes arrest/retaking provisions; live-wire is deterrent, death only if prisoner attempts escape recklessly.

holdings.text: The infiltration of policemen into prisons must generally be deprecated.

anchor.surface_text: The infiltration of policemen into prisons must generally be deprecated for, under-trial prisoners... ought to be immune from the coercive influence of the police.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General observation on policy; hypothetical here as no access shown.

holdings.text: The directive principle in Article 42 may benevolently be extended to living conditions in jails.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot do better than say that the directive principle contained in Article 42 of the Constitution... may benevolently be extended to living conditions in jails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter suggestion for humane conditions; not binding but aspirational.
